questions.question_text: Which of the following factors has the GREATEST influence on the successful implementation of information security strategy goals?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Management support

Selected Answer: B
There are two components that are asked in this question:
1. User Access Permissions
2. Alignment with data classification

Answer options C and D are general controls that can / should be applied across all classification levels. Hence, these options are wrong.

Leaves you with answer B: By reviewing the access permissions annually, or in case of job changes, the information owner is able to assess on a case by case basis, whether access rights are in accordance to the classification.

Selected Answer: B
B. Review access permissions
B. Review access permissions annually or whenever job responsibilities change

C and D can be eliminated because this is an authorization question not an authentication question. A can be eliminated because outsourcing authorization management would only be appropriate in specific contexts. This leaves B as the only possible correct answer.

choices.D: Enable multi-factor authentication on user and admin accounts
choices.A: Delegate the management of access permissions to an independent third party
choices.C: Lock out accounts after a set number of unsuccessful login attempts
choices.B: Review access permissions annually or whenever job responsibilities change

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST approach for managing user access permissions to ensure alignment with data classification?
Which of the following is the MOST critical factor for information security program success?

choices.D: Security staff with appropriate training and adequate resources
choices.C: Ongoing audits and addressing open items
choices.A: A comprehensive risk assessment program for information security
choices.B: The information security manager's knowledge of the business

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The MOST critical factor for information security program success is "B. The information security manager's knowledge of the business."

The success of an information security program depends on a number of factors, but a strong understanding of the business by the information security manager is critical. This requires the information security manager to have a good understanding of the organization's goals, objectives, operations, and risk profile, and to be able to align the information security program accordingly.

comments.content: I agree with Bro. The sec manager needs to understand the business for success and this is the best answer.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
An information security manager's knowledge of the business is important in order to understand the organization's goals, objectives, and risks, and to develop and implement security controls that are aligned with the business's needs. However, even with a highly knowledgeable information security manager, without a comprehensive risk assessment program in place, the organization may miss critical security risks and fail to allocate resources effectively to ahttps://www.examtopics.com/exams/isaca/cism/view/72/#ddress them.

comments.content: You mean this is a shit question? Because it is. Question is considered good when you can use your knowledge and experience to answer it, not when you have to guess what was the train of thought and logic of the person who made the question.

I would argue that:
-highly trained security personnel MAY miss critical security risks without a comprehensive risk assessment program, however
-untrained security personnel WILL miss critical security risks irrespective of how comprehensive the risk assessment program is

I would have answered D as it is the most fundamental of all the correct answers but this is a tough question and is open to interpretation

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Nothing is more important than a clear understanding of the business. 
You can have the most skilled people (D) - they will be useless, if security goals are not aligned with business objective. Protecting assets in a comprehensive and skilled manner will be useless anyway, if the assets are of low value to the business.

You can have the best audit program with the most skilled auditors - the audit results will be useless, if the audit scope is set wrong (e.g., selected IT assets for the audit do not represent businesses crown jewels).

Similar notion for answer option A.

Only right option is B.

B. Understanding the business allows the security manager to align the security program with the organization's goals, making it more effective and relevant. While comprehensive risk assessments and well-trained staff are important, the knowledge of the business context is crucial for making informed decisions and prioritizing security measures that support the overall business strategy.
